--- title: "Bayesian Regression - First Assessment" author: "Tiago Souza" date: "2022-08-23" categories: [econometrics, python] image: "image.jpg" --- This is my first post on Bayesian Econometrics. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import numpy as np from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression import matplotlib.pyplot as plt ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} real_estate = pd.read_csv('Real estate.csv') real_estate.head(3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
No X1 transaction date X2 house age X3 distance to the nearest MRT station X4 number of convenience stores X5 latitude X6 longitude Y house price of unit area
0 1 2012.917 32.0 84.87882 10 24.98298 121.54024 37.9
1 2 2012.917 19.5 306.59470 9 24.98034 121.53951 42.2
2 3 2013.583 13.3 561.98450 5 24.98746 121.54391 47.3
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} real_estate.columns = ['transaction_number', 'transaction_date', 'house_age', 'distance_mrt_station', 'convenience_stores', 'latitude', 'longitude', 'price_unit_area'] real_estate.set_index('transaction_number', inplace = True) real_estate['intercept'] = 1 real_estate.head(3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
transaction_date house_age distance_mrt_station convenience_stores latitude longitude price_unit_area intercept
transaction_number
1 2012.917 32.0 84.87882 10 24.98298 121.54024 37.9 1
2 2012.917 19.5 306.59470 9 24.98034 121.53951 42.2 1
3 2013.583 13.3 561.98450 5 24.98746 121.54391 47.3 1
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} Y = real_estate['price_unit_area'].to_numpy().reshape(-1,1) X_variables = ['intercept', 'house_age'] X = real_estate[X_variables].to_numpy().reshape(-1, len(X_variables)) X[1:5] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` array([[ 1. , 19.5], [ 1. , 13.3], [ 1. , 13.3], [ 1. , 5. ]]) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} ols_regression = LinearRegression(fit_intercept = False) ols_regression.fit(X, Y) Y_pred = ols_regression.predict(X) plt.scatter(X[:,1], Y) plt.plot(X[:,1], Y_pred, color='red') plt.xlabel('House Age') plt.ylabel('House Price of Unit Area') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-6-output-1.png){width=593 height=429} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} alpha_ols, beta_ols = ols_regression.coef_[0] print(alpha_ols, beta_ols) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 42.43469704626291 -0.25148841908534514 ``` ::: :::
